Award.AwardTitle: Sensing, Modeling, and Control of Smart Sustainable Microgrids

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: This project considers both theoretical and practical aspects of
response, control, and status of the University of Hawai`i Manoa (UHM) campus
electrical microgrid and studies its behavior when distributed renewable energy sources
are added. This project will transform the UHM campus's electrical distribution network
into a more modern, intelligent and responsive microgrid which relies on a greater share
of locally generated energy and energy efficient practices. Three interlinked research
projects will be integrated into the education program on smart grids, renewable energy,
and energy efficiency. The first component assembles all relevant information about the
state of the microgrid and surrounding environment. A second component models and
analyzes the microgrid using probabilistic signal processing and networking models to
accurately predict the state of the microgrid and detect anomalous events (e.g. ramps in
amount of solar PV produced and electrical grid outages). Once accurate models are
constructed and verified through simulations and data gathering, the third project
provides decision-making capability for the microgrid using distributed control and
optimization algorithms to create a secure and stable microgrid to reduces costs and
energy use. Students and faculty will work in a newly created smart campus energy lab
(SCEL) which will house the data and networking components of the UHM campus
microgrid.

Broader Impacts: UHM researchers and students will be able to combine what they
learn in the classroom with theoretical and practical research projects in the SCEL and on
the UHM campus microgrid. This understanding and practical knowledge will lead to
better insight on the design and integration of new technology for the microgrid and
future utility-scale smart grids. Through collaborations with the Native Hawaiian
Science and Engineering Mentorship Program (NHSEMP) and the Society of Women
Engineers (SWE), the project will also target underrepresented students. This project
differs from other smart sustainable microgrids being deployed at other academic
institutions and communities as our energy profile is unique (Hawaii pays the highest
electricity prices in the nation), we will incorporate large shares of distributed renewable
energy (rooftop PV), and Hawai`i has unique micro-climates (no heating and wide
variability in rainfall and cloud cover).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed novel techniques to enable microgrids to collect data about local weather and electrical conditions, analyze this information, and use it to perform optimal control of buildings and equipment. These techniques allow a microgrid to make best use of renewable and conventional resources, both on-site and in the wider grid. The project used the University of Hawaii (UH) as a testbed. Results from the three interconnected parts of this project are reported below.

Sensing and monitoring. This component assembles all relevant information about the state of the microgrid and surrounding environment. Students designed and tested several generations of self-powered weather sensor nodes, which formed a distributed, wireless network to monitor environmental conditions on the campus (e.g. solar irradiance, temperature) to understand UH's environment as more solar PV is deployed on campus. Students focused on making the “weather boxes” energy-efficient, reliable, accurate, weatherproof and low-cost, e.g., designing custom communication protocols to efficiently relay data while maximizing sleep time and minimizing transmission power. Students also created modular, easily maintainable software to store sensor data on a central server and storage system. This communication and storage framework is also suited to hold electrical grid data and building energy data gathered in real time. Important issues in this portion of the project included resource allocation (sensor placement), data fusion and mining. This data collection system also supported the higher-level components of the project. Work also considered optimal placements of a fixed number of sensors given a finite number of placement locations and assumptions about underlying probability distributions. This is an integer programming problem that is NP complete, but heuristic greedy solutions were found along with bounds for performance.

Modeling and analysis. The project developed novel ways of forecasting solar irradiance and energy using zenith angle, adaptive filters, and unbalanced cost functions. The project showed that using unbalanced cost functions such as the LinLin, LinEx and convex piecewise linear (CPWL) cost functions when training forecast models provides more useful estimates of short-term renewable energy resources, as in many cases overestimating these resources can be more costly than underestimating these resources. This work was further extended to create probabilistic forecasts of renewable energy resources, which can be used for optimal resource allocation when the cost function is asymmetrical and time-varying. The project also developed novel ways of detecting bad data in a monitoring network using online density estimation methods. Analyzing the spatial and temporal dependency between the measurements, the proposed algorithm identifies the bad data. Two approaches were considered: using an online density estimation method and a sparse online one class support vector machine. Both methods identify bad data that conventional tests such as the residual method cannot detect. The sparse online one class support vector machine has advantages in that the algorithm has low computational complexity.  Finally, the project also looked at distributed state estimation at the distribution level with distributed renewable energy sources (DREG) (i.e. solar PV).  This work used graphical methods to describe states.  We looked at second order correlation models of DREG and look at using simpler graphical models (e.g. trees) to represent these graphs.  A detection problem was formulated and measures such as the Kullback-Leibler divergence and Area Under the Curve were used to assess approximations.  For large number of states tree approximations in general do not work well.

Control and optimization. This section included three projects. Methods were developed to optimize thermostat setpoints throughout the day in a large building, based on the expected cost of power each hour. This uses an innovative problem formulation which considers the building owner's willingness to pay for improvements in comfort (instead of simply setting sharp bounds on the allowed temperature range). A second project developed a sensing and control platform and novel control strategies for electric water heaters, based on approximate dynamic programming and stochastic linear programming. Both of these controllers can act as "smart agents", continuously optimizing settings on the user's behalf, based on model predictive control and a representation of the user's economic demand function for comfort. These controllers can make best use of the flexibility of consumers and building energy systems to help integrate renewable resources. The project also developed an iterative auction design for coordinating power production and price-responsive loads on any grid scale (including microgrids). This uses a hierarchical computation and communication system which allows for virtually unlimited scaling using commodity internet connections and embedded processors.

This project also led to the enhancement of the UH Smart Campus Energy Lab and the establishment of the UH Smart Power Lab, both devoted to improved coordination of supply and demand in high-renewable power grids and microgrids, with a strong focus on undergraduate research.
